title: Oil Prices Get a Pop as Inventories Fall
text:
© Reuters.

Investing.com – And unexpected decline in weekly oil inventories pushed oil prices higher Wednesday, the West Texas Intermediate hovering around the key $55 per barrel area.

fell by about 1.7 million barrels for the week ended Oct.18, the Energy Information Administration said.

Analysts expected a rise of about 2.23 million barrels, according to forecasts compiled by Investing.com.

rose 1.3% to $55.17 at 11:21 AM ET (15:21 GMT). They were around $54.55 just before the release of the numbers.

London , the global benchmark, rose 1.1% to $60.33.

“The reason for the draw is because imports fell by over 400,000 barrels to reach below 6 million for the first time in a while,” Investing.com analyst Barani Krishnan said. “It probably became obvious to many that you don’t need to import as much with (refinery run rates at 85% of capacity.)”

“Also, we had a decent tick-up in exports, which have now reached almost 3.7 million barrels,” Krishnan added.

U.S. oil production remained at 12.6 million barrels per day.

fell by 3.1 million barrels, compared with an expected drop of 2.27 million barrels. dropped by about 2.72 million barrels, versus forecasts for a decline of about 2.8 million barrels.

“The market’s focus, accordingly, is on the continuous slump in distillate and gasoline inventories that are busting expectations,” Krishnan said. “And, of course, talk of even more OPEC cuts despite Russia playing mind games as always with the market.”
description: Oil Prices Get a Pop as Inventories Fall
